short: When a user loads a page on your website.
long: A page view is counted each time a user loads or reloads a page on your website. It helps track how often specific pages are accessed, regardless of whether it's the same user or a different one.

short: A visit to your site that can include multiple actions.
long: A session is a group of user interactions with your website within a given time frame, typically 30 minutes of inactivity. It can include multiple page views, events, and conversions.

short: A unique visitor to your site.
long: A user refers to a unique individual who visits your website, typically identified by a device or browser using cookies. Multiple sessions from the same person count as one user.

short: The percentage of sessions with no further interaction.
long: Bounce rate is the percentage of single-page sessions where the user left the site without interacting further. A high bounce rate can indicate low engagement or irrelevant content.

short: When a user completes a desired goal.
long: A conversion occurs when a user completes a predefined goal, such as signing up, making a purchase, or submitting a form. It's used to measure the effectiveness of a website or campaign.

short: An action a user takes on your site.
long: An event is any interaction or behavior a user performs on a site, like clicking a button, playing a video, or downloading a file. Events help measure engagement beyond simple page views.

short: Where your visitors are coming from.
long: Traffic source identifies the origin of your visitors, such as search engines, social media, direct visits, or referral websites. It helps track how people are finding your site.

short: Percentage of users who leave from a specific page.
long: Exit rate measures how often users leave your site from a particular page, helping identify which pages cause users to drop off most frequently.

short: Percentage of users who clicked on a link or ad.
long: CTR is calculated by dividing the number of clicks by the number of impressions, indicating how effective your links or ads are at generating interest.

short: When content is shown to a user.
long: An impression occurs each time your content, like an ad or listing, is displayed on a screen. It does not require the user to click or interact.
